newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - July 17.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - July 17.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

Video distribution group Network Entertainment yesterday announced it had put itself in voluntary administration and suspended its shares which had collapsed from A$2.00 to 11 cents since the float on the Australian Stock Exchange eight months ago. Network had experience a series of profit downgrades and departures from its board. Page 1.

WMC has halted its A$157 million plans to expand its St Ives gold-processing plant in Western Australia due to the fall in gold prices that followed the Reserve Bank's sale of most of its gold reserves. WMC had planned to replace and double the plant capacity but will now only refurbish it at a cost of A$30 million. Page 21.

Rumours of a takeover of Joseph Gutnick's Great Central Mines by Canadian-based Barrick Gold Corp propelled shares in Gutnick's gold producer to a gain of more than 25 percent since last Thursday. Barrick would not comment on the takeover speculation but said it had sent a team to Australia to seek opportunities. Page 21.

Australian gold mining companies are targeting their weaker competitors who are struggling to survive following the Reserve Bank's gold reserve sell-off. LionOre Australia managing director Barry Eldridge and Kimberley Resources chairman Miles Kennedy both expressed interest in the takeover prospects in Australia. Kimberley is part of the South African JCI group. Page 21.

Building materials company CSR Ltd plans to reduce costs in its construction materials division by A$65 million over the next two years in order to deliver earnings growth. CSR hopes to reduce the division's operating costs by A$44 million, overheads by A$11 million and save A$7 million through tightening controls on product discount. Page 23.

Operations at the DuPont /Ticor sodium cyanide plant in Australia have been badly affected by the recent slump in gold prices. DuPont Australia and New Zealand chairman and managing director John Foote said yesterday that if the slump in gold prices continued, gold production would fall, in turn threatening demand for sodium cyanide from gold producers who used the cyanide extraction technique. Page 25.
THE AUSTRALIAN

The Federal Court found yesterday that Telstra had a case to answer over allegations of misleading and deceptive conduct involving service provider AAPT. The court issued an interim injunction preventing Telstra contacting AAPT customers or making statements about the financial situation of the company. Federal Court Justice Marcus Einfeld warned the litigation could harm Telstra float plans for later this year. Page 21.

Kerry Packer is reconsidering his investment in newspaper publisher Fairfax and may quit his 14.9 percent interest in the company unless the Federal Government makes its long-promised changes to media ownership rules soon. However, that seems increasingy unlikely as the next election approaches. Page 21.

WMC has decided to shelve its A$157 million expansion of its St Ives gold mine, with WMC managing director Hugh Morgan saying the collapse of the gold price, due to the Reserve Bank of Australia's recent sale of 167 tonnes of gold and the uncertain short-term outlook, had undermined the company's expansion plans for the site near Kambalda in Western Australia. Page 21.

The Visionstream cable company has been contracted by Telstra to lay pay-TV cable past only 2.5 million homes, despite Telstra's original goal of reaching 4 million homes. It is believed Visionstream has already passed more than 2 million homes, and has slowed the rollout at Telstra's request. The contract suggests that Telstra's Foxtel partner News Corporation is the only hurdle to Telstra's ending the cable rollout early and the two companies are believed to be discussing a plan that would see Telstra pay compensation of possibly several hundred million dollars to end the rollout. Page 23.

St George Bank has re-entered the A$9 billion mortgage-backed bond market with the announcement of a A$500 million issue yesterday. St George has been out of the market for six years, and finance head Peter Gow said the issue was part of the bank's goal to diversify its investor base. Page 23.

North managing director Malcolm Broomhead said yesterday the company was pursuing acquisition opportunities in zinc with a possible price of at least A$240 million in an effort to double its output of the metal. Any zinc asset is likely to be fully price due to the rise of zinc prices to seven-year highs recently. Page 23.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

Video distributor Network Entertainment Group has collapsed seven months after it listed on the Australian Stock Exchange. The company yesterday requested that all trading in its shares be suspeneded and announced it had appointed Price Waterhouse partners Gregory Hall and allan Watson as official administrators. Page 29.

Giant insurance company GIO Australia yesterday appointed Stan Howard as chairman. Howard has been acting chairman since May following the sudden death of former chairman John Lliffe. The move is expected to herald a shake-up of GIO's board with several new appointments being made over the next few months. Page 31.

Regional pay TV franchise Austar Entertainment has not ruled out the possibility of being taken over by the newly merged Fostel and Australis Media company. The addition of Austar Entertainment, which broadcasts Galaxy programmes in regional Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria, would enable Foxtel-Australis Media to extend its current subscriber base of about 300,000 by 155,000. Page 31.

Arnotts, Kodak and Nestle have announced they will invest in the A$100 million concept shops development in the Darling harbour Walk project in Sydney which is due to start in September. The companies have agreed to contribute interactive and themed retailing projects which are predicted to be industry leaders in the future. Page 33.

Du Pont Australia and associated company Conoco hope to establish a A$1 billion commercial methane production plant at their coal-bed methane project in central Queensland. The two companies are currently awaiting production results from the site which wll determine the viabiity of the project. Page 34.

The Plastics and Chemicals Industry of Australia (PACIA) released yesterday collective results for the industry in 1996, which show that after-tax profit was down 18 percent to A$262 million with total sales falling four percent to A$5.58 billion. The PACIA said changes in government policy were necessary to support the sector and prevent further decline. Page 34.
THE AGE

Telecommunications service provider AAP Telecommunications won an injunction against Telstra in the Federal Court yesterday to prevent Telstra from "stealing" AAPT's customers. Sydney Federal Court Justice Marcus Einfeld warned Telstra that the legal acton could damage the company's proposed float later this year. Page B1.

The July Westpac-Melbourne Institute Index of consumer sentiment reveals that the slide in consumer confidence has halted with consumers having the most positive attitude towards their circumstances since 1994. Attitudes to the economy however were more pessimistic with only 26 percent predicting an upswing in the economy for the coming year. Page B3.

Australian Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer announced yesterday that Australia would join action by the World Trade Organisation against India aimed at breaking down its complex barrier to imports. The announcement came as the Foreign Affairs and Trade epartment released a report celebrating the success of the recent New Horizons campaign in opening up A$1.8 billion in business opportunites for Australian firms in India. Page B3.

WC Penfold has abandoned plans to sell its A$11 million stake in Penfold Printing because of a lack of quality offers in the two months since it was put on the market. The company also warned yesterday that a reduction in full-year earnings was likely on account of company restructuring, a depressed retail sector and business rivalry. Page B3.

The importer Kia Motors Australia yesterday attempted to dampen speculation about the future of its Korean manufacturing parent company which this week was placed into "bankruptcy protection". Kia Motors Australia general manager Walter Roso described the action by the Korean Government and the firm's main creditor the Korea First Bank as a demonstration of confidence in the long-term future of the company. Page B3.

The National Australia Bank is believed to have failed in its attempt to buy U.S.-based credit card issuer Advanta Corporation. According to the publication, American Banker, NAB offered A$2.38 billion for the company but was informed it would have t improve on that price. Despite the setback NAB is still considered the most likely candidate to eventually secure Advanta Corporation. Page B1.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
